"The Z3 was an electromechanical computer designed by Konrad Zuse. It was 
the world's first working programmable, fully automatic digital 
computer.[1] The Z3 was built with 2000 relays, implementing a 22-bit word 
length that operated at a clock frequency of about 5–10 Hz.[2] Program code 
and data were stored on punched film.
The Z3 was completed in Berlin in 1941. The German Aircraft Research 
Institute used it to perform statistical analyses of wing flutter.[3] Zuse 
asked the German government for funding to replace the relays with fully 
electronic switches, but funding was denied during World War II since such 
development was deemed "not war-important".[4] The original Z3 was 
destroyed in 1943 during an Allied bombardment of Berlin. A fully 
functioning replica was built in the 1960s by Zuse's company, Zuse KG, and 
is on permanent display in the Deutsches Museum. The Z3 was demonstrated in 
1998 to be, in principle, Turing-complete.[5][6]
Thanks to this machine and its predecessors, Konrad Zuse is often regarded 
as the inventor of the computer.[7][8][9][10]"
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z3_(computer)

comments.text:
well assuming you have the proper configuration, and all your rotors are in 
the right position you will simply run the circuit in reverse. to explain, 
the first letter in your code will also be the first letter in your message 
(translated) so the circuit will be identical, and reversible simply 
because the wiring will be in the same position. so for example, if e were 
to become j, it would go through the switchboard (if applicable) and will 
either stay the same letter or change to something like k. at this point, 
it will run through the three rotors twice (six times) so it may go to y, 
than u, than t, and than around again and to x, f, and g. than it will go 
through the switchboard and, in this case, g is connected to j, so it 
becomes j. now when we reverse this, or change e to j, j will become g 
which than becomes f, than x, than t and u and y and finally k. than, it 
goes  through the switchboard to become e (because e is connected to k). 
so, to conclude, you simply move the rotors and change the switchboard to 
create an identical circuit to the first and run it in reverse, and this is 
the beauty of this system, because if the switchboard isn't connected 
properly or the rotors are in the wrong position than you will not get an 
identical circuit and your gibberish will become gibberish. I hope this 
helps, and trust me, the machine is not nearly as complicated as I have 
just made it seem, and I hope this cleared your question up :)
comments.author: Cam N.

top_comment.author: TheRhinehart86

comments.text:
It's actually even worse than Wumbo4Dayz and lenisemicolon have stated.

Typically, the settings used for the day were just used to transmit the 
settings for a particular message you were going to send out. For example, 
maybe my rotor settings are R,G,H, (the numbers on the rotors can easily 
correspond to the letters of the alphabet). So, if I want to send someone a 
message I first send them "RGHRGH" except those letters would be sent 
through enigma. So maybe it will look like "YKMTJG." Using the 'day' 
setting they could decipher that and find out this particular message is 
being sent with the rotor settings 'RGH' (they sent 'RGH' twice to ensure 
that it was clear. They were using morse code so it was a little more 
accident prone than typing on a computer).

For more information check out Simon Singh's 'The Code Book' it's fantastic 
and really well explained.
comments.author: Nicholas Lacasse

When i upgraded to my (phone/better pc) an i7 8core prosessesor with 32gb 
ram and water cooling.

instant) to 1min 22s 5ms if run through all the possibilities. 

This included the key patching.

jumps to a whooping 32mins give or take(remember, this is if it needs to go 
all the way to the final character and had tried every solution, including 
a encrypted code)

may take from 18ms- a couple millennium. Depending on the complexity of the 
key, password, and encrypting software. ﻿

comments.text:
It was non-trivial to break, both mathematically and logistically, and 
relied on having a high volume of traffic (as you do during a war.)  If you 
changed the key once a month and only sent two messages during that time, 
cryptanalysts would not have enough material to use for a break.  Every 
time the Germans changed the key it took a couple days to start decoding 
again, and some messages never got decoded because there wasn't enough 
material.

This is due to the fact that the extra characters in the German language 
did not have Morse characters for them. Morse Code was developed 
specifically for the English language, with other languages then developing 
their own transliteration for it using the original Morse Code. Even in the 
case of characters in a language which don't turn up in English, such as 
the German use of beta (β), it has a common transliteration, which is easy 
to put into morse.

comments.text:
+Georgie2500 This is just a guess, but it could be related to technical 
limitations. The whole concept is based on building pairs of letters that 
encrypt as well as decode each other on that setting, and the setting has 
to rotate through the pairs. The problem when trying to make them able to 
encrypt to itself is that, suddenly, you basically have an "additional" 
pair to account for (by splitting e.g. A - D into A - A and D - D). 

This could pose a huge problem if the way they implemented the machine was 
based on rotating through 13 different pairs, rather than allowing the 
possibility of up to 26 pairs and anything inbetween.

Again, this is just a wild guess on my part, but I doubt they just did it 
because they deliberately thought it's a neat idea if a letter never maps 
to itself.

comments.text:
+James Youngman It wasn't her German husband. She was a single woman, 
flirting with the Chess Grandmaster, remember? It was her job in Hut 8 to 
transcribe Morse Code messages intercepted from the Germans. She knew this 
particular German operator because he always began his daily transmissions 
in the same way, and like someone already said, those would not be deemed 
part of his official transmissions. And he had a fiance'.

There has been a lot of chatter about the number of combinations, who broke 
the code first, etc. If you are taking only your information from this 
movie, then realise that while this movie is much more accurate than the 
original novel and book from the 90s, it *still* took far too many artistic 
liberties with the real facts to be of much use. An Alan Turing expert was 
interviewed on the Aperiodical blog and corrected a LOT of what had been 
said in, of and about the movie facts. Not only did Hollywood's script take 
artistic liberties, but they also did a LOT of time dilation, which created 
events that didn't even happen in some instances.


It's a very informative and entertaining blog posting: 
http://aperiodical.com/2014/07/an-alan-turing-expert-watches-the-the-imitation-game-trailer/
comments.author: Carla René

to the university libraries until now; so let's get on with it.

To be short and to the point: Is Typex unbreakable? Absolutely not.

First, let's put down the proof that the Typex is actually an Enigma clone:
"While the British were busy breaking Enigma traffic, they themselves were 
using a modified version of the machine, the Typex. The British had been 
one of the many countries to purchase commercial Enigmas for study in the 
mid-1920s. Over the next decade this machine was studied and gradually 
strengthened to the point where British cryptanalysts thought it 
satisfactory for use. The Typex used five rotors plus a static reflecting 
rotor. The rotor design and ratchet arrangements were copied directly from 
the Enigma. As with the Enigma, the reflecting rotor was on the left when 
facing the machine. The two entrance rotors, IV and V, were stators. They 
could be set initially, but did not move during encipherment. This 
arrangement forms a sort of "variable plug-board" which altered with each 
message. It is but another method of defeating the isomorph attack used 
against the commercial Enigma. Rotor III was the fast rotor and drove rotor 
II, which drove rotor I in the usual manner except that the rotor rims were 
multinotched to provide for frequent rotor movement." — (Deavours and Kruh, 
1985; p. 144)

So, there's the "proof in the pudding" as it were, that Typex was an 
Enigma. I'd provide more quotes about the specifics of the Typex, but 
that's not important to this discussion.


As to the cryptanalysis of the Typex, this statement should be telling:
"Many of the cryptanalytic methods discussed for the Enigma also can be 
carried out on the Typex which is more or less a fast-stepping Enigma with 
a non-reciprocal plug board. Using a computer, the coincidence spectrum 
method discussed in connection with the Hebern machine can be adapted for 
fairly rapid solution." — (Deavours and Kruh, 1985; p. 146)

The rotor cipher machine idea was conceived of by a man named Edward 
Hebern. The reflecting rotor was something that was unique to the Enigma 
and its relatives; the machine Hebern designed did not have a reflector to 
"bounce" the signals back through the rotors. That means that unlike the 
Enigma (and most of its relatives) where the encipherment and decipherment 
processes were the same (since the cipheralphabet was reciprocal; e.g. if A 
turns to W, then W turns to A), these machines had to have a switch to 
reverse the direction of current flow through the wheels to be able to 
decipher a message. This adds some security as now a letter can become 
itself.

There's quite a body of work on cryptanalysis of Hebern-type rotor 
machines; and in this time of computers, many of the techniques used to 
break Enigma traffic are actually the same techniques used on "normal" 
machines. These attacks rely on statistics and statistical analysis in the 
breaking of the machine; and with the advent of the modern computer the 
massive amount of number crunching needed can be both automated and sped up 
inordinately.



Going back to talking about the Engima and its relatives there are quite a 
few interesting machines. The Enigma family itself, for one, provides quite 
a bit of interesting variation. Meanwhile the Swiss, the British, and the 
Italians all made Enigma clones with various modifications to the base 
machine. The British had Typex. The Italians had the OMI made commerical 
machine, where the machine had seven rotors each consisting of two pieces 
that could be mixed and matched (essentially a 14-rotor machine where the 
rotors step in pairs). And the Swiss had the NEMA machine, which 
complicated the rotor stepping in a most fascinating manner.

Then we come to the Russians and the M-125 (and the improved M-125-3) 
"Fialka" machine. The last of the machines that could be said to be based 
on the Enigma design. It did a very, very interesting thing. The Enigma's 
fatal flaw was the reciprocity of its cipher alphabet causing no letter to 
ever encipher into itself. Most of the reflector for the Fialka was the 
same as in any other Enigma clone, however four of the wires from the 
reflector were not paired as is normal, instead they went to a so-called 
"magic circuit". One of the four wires was sent to a special triggering 
relay that made the machine encipher the original character as itself; the 
other three wires were sent to a small bit of transistor electronics. This 
little piece of electronics allowed the wires to "reflect" into the others. 
In one position of the switch wire 1 translates to wire 2, 2 translates to 
3, and 3 translates to 1; flip the switch and the order is reversed.

Of course the cryptanalytic principles used against the Enigma can also be 
applied, for the most part, to the Fialka. The machine was Russian in 
design so it had 30-contact rotors (because Cyrillic) and only four of 
those contacts did something "weird". That means there is an 86⅔% 
probability of the output of the Fialka being "like" Enigma output. The 
stepping on Fialka however was rather complex, and the machine had more 
rotors than the Enigma, so that did complicate matters.



References
Deavours, C., & Kruh, L. (1985). Machine cryptography and modern 
cryptanalysis. Dedham, MA: Artech House.

comments.text:
+mrrkkemp
If I recall, weren't the Navajo Code Talkers only:
1. Used by the US.
2. Used in the Pacific Theatre.

The actual cryptographic "things" the Allies used were either boring hand 
ciphers for quick battlefield communication (who cares if the Germans break 
it; by the time they do figure out the order says "Go Attack Their Base" 
their base is already being attacked).

There were also machine ciphers ranging the gamut from the Hagelin C-36 
(the US military licensed it for their own use as the M-209), to the 
British Typex (a slightly improved CLONE of the Enigma machine really), to 
the SIGABA (a machine that no one broke until the 2000s; used by the USA). 
There was also the CCM (see my reply to TheRhinehart86 fora short blurb on 
it).

And that's the extent of my knowledge on crypto in WWII.
comments.author: AdmiralCreideiki

comments.text:
+TheRhinehart86

Nope, the Typex had the "Engima Flaw". However, the Brits did improve it in 
other ways, and used much better practices.

An example of the improvements would be the fact it can print, as well as 
supplementing the fixed plugboard with two (non-moving but settable) rotors 
as well. Also the rotors had more stepping notches (broke up the stepping 
pattern nicely, even if it was relatively regular). The printing feature is 
rather neat, as the Typex could also encode symbols, numbers and spaces 
with the printing feature, but it required the operator to remember to 
switch between encode and decode settings (unlike the Enima); it did that 
by taking three of the most unused letters and turning them into "function" 
letters. Which could be printed in the "figure shift" mode.

Finally in terms of operations they did something the Germans never did: 
Regularly replace the rotors and reflectors. The Engima Number I rotor in 
1945 was the exact same as the Number I rotor back in the 1930s, whereas 
Typex completely replaced the rotors every few months, as well as having 
different rotor sets for different operating groups. (There was also better 
and more stringent operator training.)


What you are thinking of is the CCM. Which was an add-on/modification of 
the Typex (and a similar one for the US SIGABA machine) that let the the UK 
and USA intercommunicate without showing each other their classified cipher 
machines.


The rest of your post though? Pretty much correct. German cryptanalytic 
practices were utter crap because no one wanted to work together (like what 
happened with the Allied forces before, and during the very beginning of, 
the war).

Although the Turing-Welchman Bombes are not computers; they are very clever 
machines, but they aren't computers. The Colossi could be considered early 
computers (as well they should be), but they were used on the German 
SZ40/42 teleprinter ciphers.

As to the German intelligence quality? Yeah, the Abwehr under Canaris was 
pretty much working for the Allies; I mean, half their agents basically 
went to the Allies and went "Hi, I'm a spy for the Germans. Gimme things 
(money) and I'll tell them anything you want." and the other half were the 
definition of incompetence (that the Allies were well aware of the 
existence of, because of the first group). Hell there's even speculation 
that Admiral Canaris himself was working for the Allies.



...And I just realized how long this has gotten.

comments.text:
Britain did invent a superior version of the Enigma called Typex. Typex 
used the same principle as Enigma but it was superior because it allowed 
letters to occasionally be encoded as themselves. With Enigma no letter was 
ever encoded as itself, ie. "A" would never come up as "A" on a rotor, so 
it was possible to work out which letter was which by using computers to 
find phrases where no letters matched. The Germans captured a Typex machine 
during the Battle of France but they gave up trying to decode it after a 
few weeks because they didn't have advanced enough computers for the job. 
They never broke Typex and their intelligence was generally so poor they 
never even realised the Allies had broken Enigma relatively early in the 
war.

Why didn't they use 11 plug board pairs instead of 10? The number of 
possible plugboard pairings is greatest for 11 pairs which 
yields 205,552,193,096,250 possibilities (26! / (4! * 11! *

the second E became W.

Now, this is why the Germans
thought they had an
unbreakable code.

Old-fashioned code in the past,
pen-and-paper codes that
